info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 44.

(1, 1).clue: In May 1981 would-be assassin Mehmet Ali Agca shot this man in St. Peter's Square

(2, 1).clue: Kate Winslet wears a blue diamond necklace called the "Heart of the Ocean" in this 1997 film

(3, 1).clue: The first seal designed for what is now this U.S. state depicted icebergs, igloos & the Northern Lights

(4, 1).clue: Since 1909 every government in Denmark's parliament has been this type that needs to strike deals

(6, 1).clue: The "4 questions" asked on this occasion include wondering why we have to eat unleavened bread

(1, 2).clue: Reginald Fitzurse was among the Knights who took Henry II's remark literally to rid him of this archbishop

(2, 2).clue: Keanu Reeves is a supernatural detective in this 2005 flick based on the Hellblazer comic book

(3, 2).clue: It's the calendar year depicted here in Roman numerals

(4, 2).clue: In 1978 Ricardo Bordallo was Guam's head of government & this man was its head of state

(5, 2).clue: Numerical name for the unruly group seen here during their trial in 1970

(1, 3).clue: In 1994, 31 years after the crime, Byron de la Beckwith was convicted of murdering this Civil Rights leader

(2, 3).clue: This singer starred in "Waiting to Exhale" & "The Bodyguard"

(3, 3).clue: Sleepy Bear has been this motel chain's logo since 1954

(4, 3).clue: This country's National People's Congress has had up to around 3,500 members

(5, 3).clue: Try to photograph this swift critter, and you might only get its tail, seen here

(6, 3).clue: Gunmen after this South American dictator in 1986 used rockets, bazookas, rifles & grenades--& missed!

(1, 4).clue: Yigal Amir, a student at Bar-Ilan University, is serving a life sentence for assassinating this leader in 1995

(2, 4).clue: He played Mozart in the 1984 film "Amadeus"

(4, 4).clue: Brazil has 2 federal legislative houses, the Chamber of Deputies & this

(5, 4).clue: Viceroy of India was one of the titles of this military man

(6, 4).clue: World Heritage sites in this nation include the Nasca Lines

(1, 5).clue: Ramon Mercader, who killed this man in 1940, was later awarded the Order of Lenin

(2, 5).clue: M. Night Shyamalan wrote & directed this creepy Bruce Willis-Haley Joel Osment film

(3, 5).clue: The same 2 letters in the same order make up Arkansas' postal abbreviation & the symbol of this chemical element

(4, 5).clue: This country with "Republic" in its name was less republican after a 2003 coup by General Francois Bozize

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a hefty-looking sewing kit.)  In "Moby Dick," Ahab asks Starbuck for one of these with a triangular point to pierce through materials

(6, 5).clue: Named for an adviser to Catherine the Great, this type of "village" looks deceptively impressive

(1, 1).clue: In 1917 the name of this castle that dates back to the 11th century was adopted by a royal house

(2, 1).clue: The 1924 musical revue "I'll Say She Is" made these goofy brothers legitimate Broadway stars

(3, 1).clue: In Barry Unsworth's "The Songs of the Kings", the Greek fleet bound for here is trapped by unfavorable winds

(4, 1).clue: (I'm Dr. Thomas Starzl.)  In 1967, on a patient suffering from hepatoma, I performed the first successful human transplant of this organ

(1, 2).clue: This country whose abbreviation is a conjunction joins Spain to France

(2, 2).clue: In a 1927 title, this phrase preceded "Bonnie" (it didn't precede "Birdie" until 1960)

(3, 2).clue: James Fenimore Cooper's "Mercedes of Castile" combines a love story with the voyages of this man

(4, 2).clue: This organ was first successfully transplanted in 1981, as a package deal with a heart

(1, 3).clue: The person with this title gets to appoint people to Luxembourg's Council of State & they get to stay on for life

(2, 3).clue: The big attraction of the 1923 hit "Poppy" was this future film comic as Eustace McGargle

(3, 3).clue: The hero of Neal Stephenson's "Quicksilver" has to settle the calculus dispute between Leibniz & him

(4, 3).clue: (Dr. Thomas Starzl reads the clue.)  A pioneering kidney transplant of 1954 was from Ronald Herrick to Richard Herrick, this very specific type of relative

(1, 4).clue: France has about 100,000 of these Defense Ministry employees who perform police functions outside the main cities

(2, 4).clue: The saucy 1928 musical "Paris" introduced this composer's immortal song "Let's Do It"

(3, 4).clue: This antagonist of the Crusaders looks back on his life in a novel by Tariq Ali

(4, 4).clue: He's seen here in 1967, the year of his historic operation

(5, 4).clue: Philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau was not born in France; his birthplace was this European city

(1, 5).clue: Until recently, Slovakia was part of Czechoslovakia & Slovenia was part of this

(2, 5).clue: As a servant in the musical "Bombo", he sang "Toot, Toot, Tootsie!" & "California, Here I Come"

(3, 5).clue: It's the second name of Taras, a 16th century Cossack in a 19th century Gogol novel

(4, 5).clue: (Dr. Thomas Starzl reads the clue.)  In 1992 my team transplanted a liver from one of these primates into a man

(0, 0).clue: Sentinels at the tomb walk exactly this many steps at a time before they stop & turn
